So first, need to implement a helper function to encode a given 3-character string into its integer index (0-63).

Function: int encode(const char *s) {

    // s is a 3-length string. 

    int res =0;
    for (int i=0; i<3; i++) {
        char c = s[i];
        int value;
        switch(c) {
            case 'A': value=0; break;
            case 'C': value=1; break;
            case 'G': value=2; break;
            case 'T': value=3;
        }
        res = res *4 + value;
    }
    return res;
}

#include <stdio.h>
#include <stdlib.h>
#include <string.h>
#include <stdbool.h>

#define MOD 1000000007 

typedef long long ll;

int ok(char *last4);  // Takes a 4-char array (or string).
int encode(const char *last3); // takes a 3-char string (like last3).

void initialize_memo(int n, ll (*memo)[64], int rows) {
    for (int i=0; i<=n; i++)
        for (int j=0; j<64; j++)
            memo[i][j] = -1;
}

int main() {
    int n;
    scanf("%d", &n);
    
    // Allocate memo as (n+1) rows, 64 columns.
    // Assuming row size is 64 elements per row.
    int rows_needed = n +1;
    
    ll (*memo)[64] = (ll (*)[64]) malloc( rows_needed * 64 * sizeof(ll) );
    if (!memo) exit(EXIT_FAILURE);
    
    // Initialize all to -1.
    initialize_memo(n, memo, rows_needed);
    
    // Setup start is 'TTT'.
    // 'TTT' is three characters. 
    char start[] = "TTT";
    
    // call dfs(0, start). 
    ll result = dfs(0, start);
    
    printf("%lld\n", result % MOD);
    
    free(memo);
    return 0;
}

        if( ok(last4) ) {
            // Need to create new_last3 for the next call: last3[1],last3[2], c 

            char new_last3[3];
            new_last3[0] = last3[1];
            new_last3[1] = last3[2];
            new_last3[2] = c;
            
            ll res = dfs( cur+1, new_last3 );
            ret = (ret + res) % MOD;
        }
    }
    
    memo[cur][code] = ret;

    return ret;
}

Thus, the code for dfs function.

The ok function:

int ok(char *last4) { 

    for (int i=0; i<4; i++) {

        // create a copy of last4, since we have to swap.
        char temp[4];
        for (int k=0; k<4; k++) temp[k] = last4[k];
        
        if (i >=1) {
            // swap temp[i] and temp[i-1]
            char t = temp[i];
            temp[i] = temp[i-1];
            temp[i-1] = t;
        }

        // check if AGC is present in the temp
        // check first three letters (indices 0-2)
        if (temp[0] == 'A' && temp[1] == 'G' && temp[2] == 'C') {
            return 0; // found, invalid thus return false (0)
        }
        // check indices starting from 1: 1,2,3
        if (temp[1] == 'A' && temp[2] == 'G' && temp[3] == 'C') {
            return 0; // invalid
        }
    }

    // If none of the four cases found, return 1 (ok)
    return 1;
}

Wait wait, the condition is if either of those is true in any iteration of i. So if in any of the four loops (i=0 to 3), swapping and checking the two possible AGC presence, then return false (0).

So in the code above, as soon as any one of those two if's is true, returns 0. 

The loop runs over the four i's, so if any iteration returns, otherwise after all iterations, return true (1).

Thus, this seems correct.

Now, the 'encode' function:

 int encode(const char *last3) { // last3 is a 3-char string.

    int res=0;
    for(int i=0; i<3; i++) {
        char c = last3[i];
        int value;
        // NOTE: if last3 isn't three characters, it could read past the end.
        // so it's important that the input is 3 chars long (plus possible string terminator)
        
        // assign numerical values:
        switch(c) {
            case 'A': value =0; break;
            case 'C': value=1; break;
            case 'G': value=2; break;
            case 'T': value=3; break;
            default: return -1; // invalid character, but problem guarantees only ACGT
        }
        // accumulate into res as base4
        res = res *4 + value;
    }
    return res;
}

Yes, this should work.

Declare variables n and memo as global:

#include <stdio.h>
#include <stdlib.h>
#include <string.h>
#include <stdbool.h>

#define MOD 1000000007 

typedef long long ll;

int n;
ll (*memo)[64]; // global pointer to the memo array

int ok(char *last4);
int encode(const char *last3);

void initialize_memo(int rows) {
    for (int i=0; i<=n; i++)
        for (int j=0; j<64; j++)
            memo[i][j] = -1;
}

ll dfs(int cur, const char *last3);

int main() {
    scanf("%d", &n); // n is global
    
    // Allocate memo. 
    int rows_needed = n +1;
    memo = (ll (*)[64]) malloc( rows_needed * 64 * sizeof(ll) );
    if (!memo) exit(EXIT_FAILURE);
    
    // Initialize all to -1.
    initialize_memo(rows_needed);
    
    char start[] = "TTT"; 
    ll result = dfs(0, start);
    printf("%lld\n", result % MOD);
    
    free(memo);
    return 0;
}

Wait in the code:

In the dfs function:

ret = (ret + res) % MOD;

However, in C, when using mod operation, with negative numbers, modulo can be negative. But since both ret and res are counting numbers added, their sum can safely under modulo, but the mod should be added in case addition makes a number larger than MOD. 

Thus, to prevent negative, we can cast:

ret = (ret + res) % MOD; 

But % in C has the sign of the first operand. Thus, if the sum is negative ( unlikely here because we’re adding and using mod), but better to do:

ret = (ret + res) % MOD;

But to fix possible negative, if it comes out negative, add MOD then mod again:

    ret += res;

    if (ret <0) ret += MOD;

    ret %= MOD;
